title: US Navy veteran who was wrongly locked in Thai prison is released
text:
A US navy veteran has been reunited with his family after he was locked in a Thai prison for over a year on a false charge.

Derrick Keller, the US Navy Veteran from Richmond, Texas, hugged his wife Tanya and daughter Beverly in emotional scenes on Tuesday.

The veteran had been battling with Thai authorities to release him from jail since August 2018. He was falsely accused of being the mastermind behind a Ponzi scheme that defrauded investors of millions and faced decades in prison.

Derrick was reunited with the rest of his family when he arrived back in Texas on Wednesday.

US navy veteran Derrick Keller (pictured) has been reunited with his family after he was locked in a Thai prison for over a year on a false charge

HUGE UPDATE! US Navy Veteran Derrick Keller is in South Korea and reunited with his wife and daughter. He had been in a Thai prison for 13 months for a crime he didn’t commit. #khou11 #veteran #derrickkeller pic.twitter.com/DtTdk7uGzt — Lauren Talarico (@KHOULauren) October 8, 2019

He spent a grueling 13 months in Thailand's Klong Prem prison in Bangkok and had originally feared being kept in the prison for decades.

Keller was suspected of the being involved in a fraudulent company that targeted Thai citizens after he acted in a series of corporate videos for Eagle Gates Group Co. Ltd, which is under investigation for fraudulent activity.

Part-time actor Keller always maintained his innocence and had no idea of the criminal activities the company was involved in.

His family had desperately appealed to US politicians including Gov. Greg Abbott and Sens. Ted Cruz and John Cornyn of Texas.

The army veteran remained imprisoned until - after months of local news coverage on his case - he was found not guilty on September 30.

Derrick Keller on flight home to Texas after being released from Thailand's Klong Pren prison in Bangkok

After attempting to leave the country, Thai authorities detained him again, KHOU reported.

U.S.Embassy officials finally escorted Keller onto an airplane bound for South Korea.

It is exceptional for an American facing serious charges to be acquitted by a Thai court.

According to local media, Keller’s family had been told that 95 percent of foreigners tried for a serious crime in Thai courts are found guilty.

His family wrote on his Facebook campaign page following his release: 'Just landed in Texas safe and sound, back with his family.

'There are not enough words for how happy we feel. As a family, we are taking a few days to decompress and process our emotions. Derrick is looking forward to seeing his family, friends and supporters soon.

'Thank you for all your support and prayers.'
description: US Navy Veteran Derrick Keller from Richmond, Texas was reunited with his wife and daughter at a South Korean airport on Tuesday after he was locked in Thai prison Klong Prem for 13 months.
